15144004.review:
The more Artifex Mundi games I play, the more I like them; I've played hidden object games for years, browser based and for PC and the quality Artifex put into their games really can't be ignored.
Anyway, enough of the developer arse licking, onto the pros and cons!

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]Music[/b]: Usually I'll play games like these on silent so I can listen to music/video in the background, but I found with this game I wanted to listen it. The music is beautifully atmospheric and I found myself surprised that a point and click hidden object game had better music than some AAA titles.
    [*][b]Graphics[/b]: This game looks stunning for what it is. Everything is vividly coloured and the scenes are a pleasure to take in. Yeah, the graphics aren't fantastic, but it's a point and click game, and it makes an extra effort to look pretty.
    [*][b]Storyline[/b]: The storyline picks up fast and features a short interactive sequence after the first cutscene to get to grips with how everything works, there's no faffing around getting in to the plot. I will also shamelessly admit that a couple of scenes had me getting a bit teary-eyed, so I can't complain a jot about the story-telling (however I'm a hormonal mess at the best of times, so just bare that in mind :D).
    [*][b]Difficulty settings[/b]: The game features three different difficulty modes with varying downsides, a bonus if you like a bit of punishment in the brain department.
    [*][b]Map travel[/b]: Like other Artifex Mundi games, you can quick travel using the map, which saves you a hell of a lot of time. On easier difficulty modes you can also see which areas have actions available which is a good help when you've been scouring every inch of every screen for a while!
    [*][b]Achievements[/b]: The game features a good amount of achievements which are relatively easy to accomplish (most coming from the natural progression of the storyline), making this game a good buy for people who like to 100% things.
    [*][b]Extra game[/b]: You get access to an extra, short game called The Abyss following the completion of the main story. What it lacks in duration it more than makes up for in content and boasts a couple extra achievements for those interested.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]Game interface[/b]: The UI can get a bit irritating at times, namely the massive bar that pops up at the top of the screen when you interact with things. When on the hidden object parts, clicking an interactive object before you have the corresponding piece will block off a chunk of the top of the screen. It can also feel a bit cluttered at times because of this. Not a massive issue, though when going for the timed achievements (such as getting x number of hidden objects within x seconds) it can be a bit of a hinderance.
    [*][b]Footsteps[/b]: This was the single most annoying thing in the entire game for me, which is silly in hindsight because it's such a small issue. Basically, whenever you move from scene to scene, you hear your character's footsteps. When you consider moving from room to room fairly quickly it grates - though this could just be me.
    [*][b]Buttons[/b]: This is again to do with the UI, but a different issue. There's a few buttons at the bottom of the screen that let you click to see how many bonus hidden objects you've found (in this game it's fairies and out of place items, in a few Artifex Mundi games it's been seahorses and the like), however it's right next to the map button, which means you can accidentally hit the wrong button. Again, this is more of a pet peeve for me, especially when I did it four times in a row (lel).
    [*][b]Voice and text[/b]: Unfortunately there are a few typos in the game, mainly missed words as opposed to spelling errors. There are some discrepancies between what is written and what the characters say. While it's a small error it's one I feel diminishes just how well made this game is.
[/list]

[b]Minor issues/mentions[/b]
The [b]voice acting[/b] can be a bit wonky at times, I remember a couple of scenes where it sounded like the voice actor had never heard a particular word they were saying. However the majority of the game features great voice acting.
Some [b]interactive areas[/b] were a little too big, meaning you'd end up clicking the same place again thinking it was somewhere different due to the distance from the object on the screen.
The [b]little kitty follower[/b] you get early on is definitely a major highlight of the game, I never tired of seeing it drag it's cute little butt over the UI to help me out.
I also swore blind one of the voice actors was the guy who played Randy in Trailer Park Boys, certainly made those scenes more enjoyable.

Overall I loved this game, it's of a length that you can replay it without taking too much time out of your day. It's easy to get into and even when you've left the game for a while you can easily pick it back up.
I'd recommend it to anyone, especially when you consider the price tag.

First off this game is beautiful and I often paused in the middle of everything just to soak up the interactive artwork that makes up the game though the characters come off as bit bland, wearing the same expression whenever they talk to you no matter what. Second the puzzles are very creative and fun though some are a little to vague on what they expect you to do and it can get a little frustrating as you have to figure the whole process out before you can even start working out the puzzle itself. Its nice that you have some choices in the game should you get stuck, not in the mood for a hidden puzzle? Play dominos instead. That puzzle got you stumped? Just skip it.  

I found the story a bit shallow but nicely delivered and it was a fun challenge trying to find all the elusive objects and sprites. Its surprising there's no achievement for that as they can be… well elusive but all I can say is keep your eyes pealed cause you could be looking right at one and still miss it. Naturally some might find this kind of game boring because it works on a more relaxed pace that forces you to slow down and use your brain to work out the problem but I liked being able to take my time and enjoy the atmosphere rather then speed though it guns blazing. It’s a nice change from shooting monsters and beating up bad guys. 

Its not for everyone though so if your impatient or prefer more action in your games I'd avoid this one, it will ether drive you insane or put you to sleep. But if you’re the type that likes the challenge of a good puzzle then give this one a try, just don't expect to be shocked at the story twist.

13949394.review:
Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride is another incredible Hidden Object Game from the phoenominal Artifex Mundi. This is the first game in a trilogy of tales based in the fashion of the Brothers Grimm. With this particular Artifex Mundi game, you cannot go wrong. It's a game that all ages can enjoy for its puzzles and hidden-object mini-games, but also one that holds a strong storyline which would interest all age groups. Grim Legends is like playing a fairy tale as if they were reading a book.

[b]Story[/b]
Grim Legends focuses around a woman who's sister is kidnapped on the day of her wedding by a strange bear. There's definately something strange about the bear and the whole situation. The protagonist decides to go off on her own and rescue her sister. In the process of recovering her, the player stumbles upon a long forgotten curse that only a mysterious old hermi women knows of.

[b]Classic Artifex Engine and Style[/b]
Artifex Mundi always combines their beautiful artwork with puzzles and hidden object games to pull together a great story. This creates a great formula which leaves you wanting more. This particular game is the first, and one of the [i]best[/i] Artifex games that I've played to date.

 [b]If you're new to the Artifex universe, I highly recommend that this be the first AM game you play.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Grim Legends holds AM's best artwork. The locations you will visit are enchanting.
- Fantastic storyline that drives the player to play more
- Great for kids and adults alike
- Various difficulties (as in all AM games)
- Various styles of hint systems with adjusting difficulty
- Just an all around solid, great game

[b]Cons:[/b]
- A Short game, even combined with the Bonus content. If you like Artifex Mundi games, you already know that many of them are short games. AM is changing this with their newer releases such as [i]Grim Legends 2[/i] or [i]Nightmares of the Deep 3[/i].
- Some of the voice work, while nice and clear, are a bit overplayed or cheesy, but it doesn't get in the way of enjoying the game or the story line. This is also a feature that is currently being vastly improved with newer Artifex games.

[b] Verdict?[/b] - [b]8/10[/b] 
Grim Legends is probably one of Artifex's best titles. It is family friendly and is fun for all ages. This is just a fantastic game for anyone who enjoys hidden object games, puzzles, or just great adventure/fairy tale stories. I can very confidently say that I am ecstatic that I found this game, otherwise I would not have found Artifex Mundi. A high recommendation.

If you're curious about any other Artifex Mundi games, I have and will continue to do many reviews on their great titles. If you liked the Grim Legends title, [i]Grim Legends 2[/i] is currently available on Steam as well. Please read my review for it if you are interested.

13868950.review:
Colorful images and haunting sounds are the key points of attraction in Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride, a hidden-object adventure game from Artifex Mundi. 

A good fantasy story ties together the simple gameplay: use logic to piece together items you find in the environment so you can solve puzzles and proceed with the story. Some of the solutions don't make a lot of sense (nor do some of the hidden objects you have to find), but if you ever get stuck, you can fall back on the hint system to make regular progress. 

While it can be absorbing to seek solutions hidden within the beautiful images, it bothers me that there is only one solution to every puzzle. Sometimes the “correct” solution makes less sense than something I came up with on my own. Also bothersome is the protagonist's tendency to leave behind useful items like a knife or a rope, only to search for new ones in the next puzzle. I'd like Artifex Mundi games more if they had flexibile puzzle solutions (like the Deus Ex games), encouraging creativity and improving replay value.

As long as Artifex Mundi sticks to their formula, they are unlikely to make a game better than Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride. I can't complain too much, though; simple, bite-sized games like this can be very satisfying to play once in a while, especially in an environment populated by so many long games. 

(Rating: 7.5/10 “Good”)

This is easily the best hidden object adventure I've ever played in terms of production quality. The quality of the visuals, music and voice acting are both superb for the genre (I was especially amazed by the smooth, but still painted-looking animations.) The game brings all the features of modern HO games, map, hints, selectable difficulty level, easy puzzles, lots of achievements and collectables and an alternative for HO scenes (in this game it's domino).

The plot is good too for the genre, not too blatantly obvious, though not that surprising either. I liked how it's not about a guy saving a love interest, but a woman trying to save her sister. And I loved the ending a lot! The focus was different than most HO games I've played.

In the first half of the game instead of word-list HO scenes, the player has to combine items based on images. I haven't met with this type of HO scene before, it was refreshing after the endless word-lists of other games.

The only thing I kinda missed is the feature they had in 'SEASON OF MYSTERY: The Cherry Blossom Murders' where if you click on an object in a HO scene, it shows the item's silhouette.

There were some genre-typical ridiculous elements, like having to light up a torch with a ray of focused light in a multi-step puzzle, next to a field of dozens of candles. Also having to be basically a cleptomaniac and steal quite a few things from your innocent neighbours. (I had to steal a candle, a crochet needle, a fan and a teacup from the same windowsill throughout the game + even had to cut off a piece of their curtain ^^;; )

PS: That kitten helper is the cutest thing ever :D

13463655.review:
Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride is a hidden object adventure game by Artifex Mundi. Most of the Artifex Mundi games on Steam are hidden object games, and all of the ones I've played have been of very high quality. But when I started playing The Forsaken Bride, I knew it was something special.

First, lets talk about the gameplay. The hidden object scenes and puzzles are basically the same as any other Artifex Mundi game. Items are collected or created through hidden object scenes, and are also collected through exploration of the world. You explore and interact with the world using items you collect, and some of these items are used in various puzzle games. Many puzzle games are similar to those found in other Artifex Mundi games, but I found the ones in The Forsaken Bride to be more refined, varied and challenging.

I've always found the atmosphere and music to be phenomenal when it comes to Artifex Mundi games, and The Forsaken Bride is no exception. In addition, I found the artwork to be hauntingly beautiful.

What stood out to me most was the story. The execution was nearly flawless, and there was a depth and subtle intricacy that I had not found in previous Artifex Mundi games. That's not to say that the stories in other Artifex Mundi games are bad (they're actually quite good), but the story in The Forsaken Bride is truly a step above the rest.

The Forsaken Bride is the best hidden object game I've yet played, and may very well be the best Artifex Mundi game to date.

[h1]Short version: 86%[/h1]
Grim Legends features a quite long and well-written storyline with beautiful, lush graphics. The puzzles don’t exactly offer the same quality, but they still won’t leave anyone disappointed. A recommended title for hidden object enthusiasts. 

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride is the most story-oriented hidden object puzzle game I have seen in a while… even compared to other Artifex Mundi titles. Although the plot still boils down to the usual ‘stop mysterious magical evil’ formula, the characters are quite realistic in their actions and motivations. A rare sight in this genre.

This high focus on the story had an adverse effect on the puzzles themselves, as they tend to be quite repetitive. The item interaction part is almost point ‘n’ click adventure level complicated. The hidden object scenes feature the usual quality, although I have to mention that a surprisingly large number of them fall into the ‘construct a useful item’ category. Also, there is a huge amount of backtracking, so using the map feature is almost mandatory.

Despite these setbacks this is one of the strongest titles in Artifex Mundi’s portfolio. The well-crafted story and the better than average puzzles create a powerful combination that won’t let down the fans of this genre.

12935489.review:
This is a respectable HOG/adventure hybrid game that will give you several hours of casual fun.  Compared to other Artifex Mundi titles, I would rate it on par with "Nightmares of the Deep: The Cursed Heart."

The artwork for both the backgrounds and the puzzles is beautiful, as is expected for an AM game, but some of the character designs and cutscenes were a bit of a letdown.  ("I'm going to go change into my wedding dress, that looks just like my normal dress, that looks exactly the same as a third dress hanging in my room...")  

The gameplay combines several types of puzzles including:
1. Traditional hidden object screens (clearly denoted by shiny sparkles in casual mode).
2. "I Spy"-style fairy finding.  These special sprites appear on almost every close-up location detail screen.
3.  Elusive disappearing-reappearing images.  These objects blend into the larger location backgrounds and slowly fade in and out of view.  Collecting them gives you additional plot background, but they can be tricksome to locate.  
4. Classic adventure gaming puzzles.  (i.e. Find objects, use/combine with other objects, backtrack everywhere)
5. Recipes.  AM loves their crafting worktables.
6. Mini-games.  Incredibly easy time-wasters and brainteasers such as interlocking puzzles, tile-swapping, rotating pieces, matching symbols, and general pattern recognition.

They also threw in a cat companion who counts as a special use item, which I found to be a fun little gimmick.

I started on Expert mode, and only got stuck twice (figuring out what to do with the ladder, and figuring out how to light the torch.)  Everything else was pretty straightforward.  If you are a veteran of the genre, you will most likely be playing on auto-pilot.  

My biggest complaint was actually the pacing.  They tried to build in a learning curve for new players, but it just makes the start of the game feel very slow and tedious, and the end of the game feel like a flash-round, mini-game gauntlet.  This becomes an added issue when some of the achievements are not only time-challenges (like 1-minute dominoes), but can only be earned in story mode.  If you miss those achievements on the first playthrough, have fun slogging through tutorial mode all over again, or replaying the bonus level ad nauseum, just to get to an applicable puzzle.  (It doesn't help that you are already required to fully play through the game twice over if you want to earn all of the achievements.)

I will say that for once with an AM game, I found the bonus level gameplay more enjoyable than the main story.  It's no wonder they directly reused some of the level's puzzle content for "Cursed Heart."

Overall, I would give this game a 7/10.

Gegen Ende wird es mit den Rätseln etwas einseitig und im Spielmodus "leicht" ist jede Aufgabe schnell schaffbar. Man kann aber auch auf normal oder schwer spielen und hat dann länger was vom Spiel. Die Dialoge sind zugegebenermaßen sehr einfach gestrickt und von einem "echten" Adventure meilenweit entfernt. Da ich das Spiel im "Halloween-Sale" erstanden habe (es hat da ca. 1.50-2,50€ gekostet), finde ich es seinen Preis für die kurze Spielzeit auch wert. Mehr als 5€ würde ich dafür allerdings nicht bezahlen wollen und warte daher immer auf die Sale-Angebote. : ) Gruselig ist das Spiel im übrigen überhaupt nicht. Nur das Bonus-Level, welches nach dem Durchspielen freigeschaltet wird, hat gruselige Bildelemente (psychedelische Umgebung, Totenköpfe, Altare usw.) An einer Stelle merkt man auch sehr stark, dass die bevorzugte Zielgruppe der Spielemacher wohl Frauen sein sollen, da im Spiel sehr oft Klischees zu weiblichen Idealen und Träumen bedient werden (Kosmetik, Romantik, Heirat usw.) Mehr verrate ich aber nicht! Alles im allem finde ich das Spiel seeeehr gelungen und kann es weiterempfehlen!!!

Colorful and fun, with a good story by the standards of the genre.  Jump map, little backtracking, adjustable difficulty.  On casual difficulty, hints recharge very quickly.  

Hidden object scenes are very seldom straightforward. Usually there's a fun twist or two to them, but if you find them tiresome or frustrating, you can choose to play dominos instead.  

Puzzles are varied and as far as I can remember never repeated.  (If any WERE repeated, this was so inoffensive that it didn't stick in my memory.)

Art, cut scenes and animations are of high quality for this genre and release year.  Voice acting is appropriate and never sounds amateurish (a common pitfall in these games).  Cute animal companion is present and accounted for (a kitten), but thankfully not over-used.

Extras include soundtrack (that you can save to your Documents folder with a click), wallpapers, replayable hidden object scenes and the traditional extra chapter.  During the main game, there are 30 colllectable fairies ('spirits') and 28 morphing objects to find as optional objectives.  

Easily worth full price ($7.99 CDN at time of writing).  A quality evening's entertainment.

This game combines a fairytale story with  hidden object and logic puzzles. You are a heroine who must travel through different settings, combine objects to create tools  and interact with characters. One of my favorite parts of this game is the beautiful artwork. I found the story line for this particular game very predictable and the cut scenes  melodramatic but I still enjoyed the game play. I also find this style game very relaxing since there is no time limit to accomplish tasks/games.I also reccomend this game for ages 10 and up since the modes allow you to vary the difficulty. Depending on the mode you choose, you can look for where on the map you need to take action,  you can press the hint button (reloads at different speeds) and you can skip any of the puzzle games. I believe most people would finish this game in 10-12 hours. One thing to keep in mind for this style game is that the objects you must find can be in really odd arbitrary places and a lot of objects you find are broken, so you have to fix them before use. You will have to go back and forth between settings in order to open trunks/objects and create tools. This particular game isn't as outrageous in the location of objects but it is something you have to accept in order to enjoy these hidden object games. There are dozens of these style games, so if you like it there are a wide variety of stories with the same game mechanics.

TLDR
Fairytale narrative with hidden picture and logic puzzles.

PROS
-Beautiful Artwork
-Varying difficulties (modes) 
-Simple game mechanics
-No time limits for puzzles
-All players can beat/ complete the story
-Enjoyable for a variety of ages

CONS
-Predictable story line
-Melodramatic cut scenes
-Must sustain disbelief when finding objects in odd locations

40603217.review: The Forsaken Bride takes place in a fantasy setting and I would assume is a typical hidden object game if you are familiar with them. If you haven't played these games before it's basically a mix of point and click adventure and puzzle solving including hidden object screens. The puzzles are beautifully designed and have pleasing variety. The game also does a nice job of explaining how to play and where to go. I only played through on casual difficulty so it was very easy but it can be made more  challenging. There was some backtracking which can be annoying but here it's not too bad. This is the first hidden object game I've played, but likely the first of many more Artifex Mundi games in the future.

40152183.review:
Awesome puzzle game.
More puzzle games should be like this.

The puzzles were simple and straight forward, but required some thinking outside of the box.

Pros:
-The "hidden objects" puzzles were the perfect level of taxing for a casual gamer.
-And there were two methods for completing them - You could search for the hidden objects, or play a dominos puzzle... And you could switch back and forth at will, meaning you aren't locked in to either one.
True flexibility.
-The storyline was interesting and consistant. And not too complex, meaning the focus really was on the puzzles.
-Plenty of options means you don't feel "rail roaded".
- All current goals can be achieved in your location, or in a few different nearby location screens, so there's no trekking back and forth across the map.

Cons:
-The art and graphics were pretty basic, but definitely within reason.
-The storyline was a little bit cliche, so if you're looking for lifechanging storylines this isn't the game for you.

40125684.review: Я уже очень давно не играл в жанр "поиска предметов", поэтому The Forsaken Bride стала для меня приятным сюрпризом. Игра удивила хорошей постановкой и интересным (пускай и немного предсказуемым) сюжетом, а также продвинутым для жанра игровым процессом, с кучей паззлов и даже картой для быстрого премещения между экранами. "Поиск предметов" тут вообще можно пропустить полностью, заменив его партиями в домино, и игра превратится в упрощенный, но очень красивый и увлекательный квест. В общем, The Forsaken Bride оставляет положительное впечатление и отлично подходит для того, чтобы отвлечься от "крупных" игр и поиграть в что-нибудь попроще. Лично у меня она даже разбудила интерес к жанру, но вторая игра в которую я сыграл от этих разработчиков оказалась не настолько крутой, зато смотивировала написать эту рекоммендацию к The Forsaken Bride. Если вы давно присматривались к жанру "поиска предметов", но не знали с какой из них начать, я советую начинать именно с этой, она без шуток хорошая.

[h1]Почему я опять запустил игру от Artifex Mundi?[/h1]
Я не могу ответить на этот вопрос. Это как конфета «Коровка», вкус которой отнюдь не восхищает, но иногда соблазняет на ещё одну… Брррр. [url=https://corpuscula.blogspot.ru/2011/05/guilty-pleasure.html]Guilty Pleasure.[/url]

[h1]Вкратце[/h1]
Сказка про социальное расслоение по имущественному цензу, обида на несправедливость и сделанная глупость с радостью подхваченное «Шотаплохим из ямы». Что именно это шотоплохое хотело не понятно, но оно покусилось на самое драгоценное — на сестру протагонистки и [spoiler]хочет на ней жениться, подарив по всей видимости власть над неведомым.[/spoiler]  Ему точно не поздоровится, хотя бы из чувства зависти. В истории замешан медведь, который в начале сидел в придорожных кустах по видимому в засаде.

[h1]Реальность в ощущениях[/h1]
Я могу сравнить это произведение только с серией [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198084019881/recommended/259740/]Nightmares from the Deep[/url]. По сравнению с той серией качество картинки безусловно возросло, в какой-то степени до предела  — что есть, то есть, но актёрскую игру так и не завезли. Кроме того, меня безмерно раздражает, что всё приходится делать вам, а NPC просто говорят чего их душеньки угодно, а дальше терпеливо и молча ждут, когда вы это посреди леса без магазинов и интернета достанете прямо здесь и сейчас! Я опять выяснил, что не люблю искать предметы, но альтернатива в виде вариации домино мне нравится ещё меньше. Но всё таки я дошёл до конца — и это опять всё та же конфета «Коровка». Видимо в будущем опять захочу «укусить» что-то подобное опять…

39667942.review:
Full disclosure: I won this game in a random drawing from (as far as I know) a random user unaffiliated with the publisher/developer, and I have no connections to them, either.

This Hidden Object Game (HOG) was the first that I played with such high quality visuals and sound. There's voice acting surprisingly often, the art is quite lovely (even among HOGs, which already look pretty darn good, generally), I was surprised by how many animations there were, and there was a (sorry for redundancy) surprising amount of 3D stuff that came up in the game. I have been playing a few HOGs, and aside from attractive hand-drawn stuff, most other aspects of the game (except for the puzzles) tend to be quite lackluster, and Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride excelled in areas many of these games are lacking.

I found this game to be longer than some HOGs, though it's certainly still pretty short. Then again, that aspect of HOGs actually appeals to me a fair bit. The storyline is decent enough, though it [i]is[/i] an HOG, which, in my opinion, means the story will generally be pretty poor. It's not a great plot, and there's some stuff that made me laugh and roll my eyes, but it was a far more memorable plot than most HOGs I've been trying (I'm fairly new to the genre). The characters aren't all that great, but again, it's an HOG, so that's par for the course, at least in my opinion.

All in all, from my experience thus far, if you've played one HOG, you've pretty much played them all. They all have differing amounts of window dressing and levels of attractiveness/user friendliness, though, and I think that Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride is an excellent entry into the genre, as it's basically "just another one" while having that much more glitz and glamour than the rest.

I think this is my favorite HOG I've played to date, I liked most of the puzzles, and it even has a bonus post-story adventure that is like a bite-size little game of its own that wraps up a loose end of the storyline nicely. I liked this so much that I bought a three-pack of this game and its two sequels (gave the duplicate first game away in a drawing), and have played through Grim Legends 2 and eagerly await giving 3 a go.
